summary: Debates about Grant often invoke international law to cast him as an early advocate of rules‑based diplomacy—citing his push for arbitration of the Alabama Claims and insistence on treaty obligations—as evidence of a statesman who favored peaceful, legal dispute resolution. Conversely, critics use international‑law arguments to accuse him of selectively invoking legal norms to justify expansionist or politically expedient moves (e.g., Santo Domingo annexation efforts), portraying inconsistency between principle and practice.
